title: 109_s1519
content: The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005, also known as the Small Business Act, is amended to include a new section on agency restructuring or termination of facility use. This new section is designated as section 37. The new section 37 of the Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 defines key terms such as agency, qualifying termination or restructuring, restructuring, and small governmental jurisdiction. The new section 37 of the Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 defines key terms and requirements for agencies and entities regarding qualified termination or restructuring. Prior to any qualifying termination or restructuring, agencies and authorized entities must conduct a detailed analysis of the impact on small businesses and governmental jurisdictions. The analysis should include a description of the small business concerns. Prior to any qualifying termination or restructuring, agencies and authorized entities must conduct a detailed analysis of the impact on small businesses and governmental jurisdictions. This includes describing the affected small business concerns and governmental jurisdictions, estimating their numbers, outlining efforts to minimize adverse economic impacts, and proposing alternative solutions to reduce overall impact. Prior to any qualifying termination or restructuring, agencies and authorized entities must conduct a detailed cost-benefit analysis of the economic impact on small business concerns and small governmental jurisdictions in states where the impact exceeds $100,000,000. Prior to any qualifying termination or restructuring, agencies and authorized entities must conduct a detailed cost-benefit analysis of the economic impact on small business concerns and small governmental jurisdictions in states where the impact exceeds $100,000,000. The analysis includes evaluating costs and benefits to small businesses, providing alternatives, and preparing a summary report. Prior to any qualifying termination or restructuring, agencies and authorized entities must conduct a detailed cost-benefit analysis of the economic impact on small business concerns and small governmental jurisdictions in states where the impact exceeds $100,000,000. The analysis includes evaluating costs and benefits to small businesses, providing alternatives, and ensuring transparency in the analysis process. The measures for ensuring transparency in the analysis process include incorporating an executive summary, detailing assumptions and discount rates, referencing all data sources, providing appendices with model documentation, and reporting formal sensitivity results. The agency or entity must publish a draft economic analysis on its website and provide notice in the Federal Register with a 60-day comment period before taking final action on a qualifying termination or restructuring. After considering comments, a final economic analysis must be published on the website and a notice in the Federal Register. After publishing the final economic analysis on its website and in the Federal Register, an agency or entity must submit it to the Comptroller General of the United States for review within 90 days. The Comptroller General will then analyze the submission and publish a report on its sufficiency. If the analysis is deemed insufficient, the agency or entity must repeat the required procedures. An agency or entity must wait for a satisfactory review from the Comptroller General of the United States before taking final action on a qualifying termination or restructuring. Small businesses or governmental jurisdictions affected by the termination/restructuring can file for judicial review within 90 days of the final economic analysis notice being published. The Court of Appeals will expedite the review of petitions related to qualifying termination or restructuring actions to determine if they are arbitrary, capricious, or not in accordance with the law. These requirements apply to any termination/restructuring where final action has not yet occurred at the time of the enactment of the Act.
